The case centers about the interpretation of a Spanish decree which lays down the principle that, when a ship has more Britons than foreigners in its crew, it is to be regarded as piratical, if it attack a Spanish ship. My opponente may maintain that the Dutch vessel stood by, while the capture was being made, that the two vessels therefore constituted a unit, and that when so regarded the Britons were in the minority. Consequently this was not an act of piracy. ,

I reply that the Dutch have no legal claim to any booty, because the property was not brought within their fortified lines.² Besides the Dutch vessel’s share can come only from what the British ship has. The capture was made by the

British ship, and in the intentor the Spanish decree she was .

clearly a pirate, so that the Dutch have no claim whatsoever.
